descriptions.content:
In the spoken language, many verbs consist of a noun followed by a verbalizer. The most frequently encountered verbalizers are རྒྱག་ “to make,” བྱེད་ “to do,” བཏང་ “to send.” The noun that precedes the verbalizer is often disyllabic, and is sometimes made up of verb roots that function as autonomous verbs in the written language. In the spoken language, verbs can be monosyllabic, disyllabic or trisyllabic.

In Literary Tibetan, verbalizers are not used and verbs are usually monosyllabic or sometimes disyllabic:

  • སློབ་ “To learn” (L), སྦྱོང་ “To study” (L) = སློབ་སྦྱོང་བྱེད་ “To study”
  • བརྟག་ “To examine” (L), དཔྱད་ “To research” (L) = བརྟག་དཔྱད་བྱེད་ “To examine”
  • ངལ་གསོས་ “To rest” (L) = ངལ་གསོ་རྒྱག་ “To rest”
  • མགོ་སྐོར་ “To trick” (L) = མགོ་སྐོར་བཏང་ “To trick”
  • མགོ་འཁོར་ “To be tricked” (L) = མགོ་སྐོར་ཐེབས་ “To be tricked”
  • ཁྲོ་ “To get angry” (L) = ཁོང་ཁྲོ་ལང་ “To get angry”
